body: Ill have a look next week on this. But sounds promising.
Superseeded by PR #631

I would say -1 for now to replace Jenkins with GitHub Actions. I think we should first cleanup the tests and have a faster build. Else, we will have bunch of GH Actions jobs, and potentially "banned".
@jbonofre ok make sense, let me close this PR and reopen it when needed.
LevelDB will be removed from `master` soon.
@alechenninger do you have time to refactore this PR as a complete new plugin or do you want me to do it ? Thanks !
I tried several times but it works fine in maven. Maybe only IntelliJ is impacted.
Johnzon is fine using jsonb. I've started the review and rebase anyway.

Overall the goal is to enable to use json-b and use the json-b contract (ie neither johnzon nor jackson must appear in compile scope in theory - until it is to be transitive but I'm speaking on a pure build perspective). I assume it should be tested with both impl - and maybe yasson - to ensure some portability - at least manually for the first round.
After the question of the default in the distro can be discussed. The least changing is jackson but the most apache is johnzon and for AMQ it should be very close once fully migrated to json-b api so at the end I'd say 50-50 ;).
No update from contributor.
@chammp thanks for the update. I think that AMQ-5790 already fix the issue, but I have to double check.

Your change basically breaks the client. For instance, `ActiveMQSslConnectionFactoryTest` is stuck, up to `OutOfMemory`.

I'm closing the PR as it's not correct. Feel free to reopen it with correct change: it should pass the Jenkins build (now enabled on PR).

@gtully - Any thoughts on this Gary? This change makes sense to me at first glance but it looks like you initially added the check for just XA transactions [here](https://github.com/apache/activemq/commit/f7ff4c25e13133132c3103141a5179c93e43b536). I was curious if there was a reason you didn't initially include local Tx as well?

@michaelandrepearce did you have time to review this PR ? If you have some time to do so, it would be great. I would like to merge this PR pretty soon as it's blocking my other PRs (JDK11 build, Spring5 update, Log4j2 update, ...). Thanks !
Closing this as it'll be cherry-picked to the other branches after being merged to master.
Closing this as it'll be cherry-picked to the other branches after being merged to master.
Thanks for tackling the partition feature as part of this refactor.

I'm rebasing on `master`. As said in my previous comment: can you please verify and eventually approve this PR ? It blocks me to create the dependency PRs (JDK11 build, Spring5 update, Log4j2 update, ...).
@mattrpav it's dependent updates (removing some useless dependencies now).
I've (hopefully) simplified that shouldForward() method, per the comments. Thank you for the review, @gtully !

> @michaelandrepearce did you have time to review this PR ? If you have some time to do so, it would be great. I would like to merge this PR pretty soon as it's blocking my other PRs (JDK11 build, Spring5 update, Log4j2 update, ...). Thanks !

Hi @jbonofre sorry just been busy with work, haven't gone through every change in this PR, but regarding the bits around partitioning which i had raised initially, it looks good to me, you've fixed my concern.
Rebasing to fix the build issue.
@michaelandrepearce @mattrpav thanks for your review guys ! I'm rebasing/fixing build and I will merge. Thanks again !
@charlie-cyf can you please rebase/squash your two commits ? Thanks !
Sure, new PR: https://github.com/apache/activemq/pull/641

For the record, you don't have to create a new PR. You can simply update this one with `git rebase -i origin/master` and squash the second commit to the first one, and then you just force push `git push --force charlie-cyf:AMQ8189`.
The failing test (in `activemq-amqp`) is not related to your change (it's another flaky test ;) ). I'm testing the PR locally with `full.test` profile.
I'm testing the fix locally as `full.test` profile is not use on Jenkins by default.

> @alechenninger do you have time to refactore this PR as a complete new plugin or do you want me to do it ? Thanks !

@jbonofre @alechenninger Since this is an old PR and your availability might have changed, I can offer to also refactor this PR to help move it forward.
@jbonofre @ehossack-aws I'm available, I just commented above. Trying to better understand what we're really after with the refactoring recommendation before moving forward.
Superseded by #647

I just did a new pass. I agree with the change however, this PR needs:
1. fix the missing ASF headers in couple of files
2. rebase on `master`
I will do a new final pass and merge as soon as it's OK.

Scan on GitHub diff looks good. I'll pull this PR-down to do a build and a local poke. 

@jbonofre this change to JDK 11 is a pre-req for a bunch of other changes. Do you have any add'l planned commits? Thoughts on additional reviewers or ETA on merge?
@mattrpav the PR is ready to merge for pure JDK 11 build. I just have set of commits to use JDK11 code style (lambda, etc). I planned to be do in this PR, but it could be done in new ones.
The only think I would like to do is maven-bundle-plugin 5.1.2 update, but it breaks `activemq-pool`. I will check this.
You good with merge and then do jdk11 code style and maven-bundle in follow on PR?
@mattrpav it sounds like a plan. Let me update Jenkinsfile in the PR and I will merge. Thanks !
@gtully waiting deeper investigation, here's a simple revert of the commit causing redelivery broker plugin issue. Do you have time to investigate or do you want me to do it ? Thanks !
Please open the PR only on `main`/`master` branch.
Created PR to kick off test suite against updated Jetty
I had the PR ready already ;)
No prob. I plan on deleting this one. I was just wanting to kick off the Jenkins to verify unit tests
@mattrpav no it's fine, it's basically the same ;)

I think activemq-pool should have the permissive import "[1.1,3)" defined for javax.jms to allow runtime swapping with a javax.jms v2 spec. (Similar to how the client, camel and broker are setup).

`Import-Package: javax.jms;version="[1.1,3)"`
@mattrpav I don't think `activemq-pool` import `javax.jms`.
I'm working on identifying the build failure (test) with JDK11. The PR should be "clean" soon. By the way, I have updated `Jenkinsfile` to use JDK11 on this PR.
@jbonofre - This looks good to me, I added a small commit to fix the assembly build issue I was seeing on my system.

@jbonofre - Have you tested a full build including things like building Javadocs? I tried to build javadocs and it's breaking

I just ran mvn javadoc:jar and it blows up inside the Openwire Generator project pretty quickly.
@cshannon cool thanks for the commit ! Let me try javadoc/full build. I will fix there.

@jbonofre - Part of the the issue (at least for me) is the URLs not working that are defined in the Javadoc plugin and that is causing errors. If I remove the following links from the javadoc plugin config in the pom file it works:

`<link>http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/collections/apidocs-COLLECTIONS_3_0/</link>`
`<link>http://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-client-ga/httpclient/apidocs/</link>`
`<link>http://logging.apache.org/log4j/docs/api/</link>`

I don't know if these have any replacements we can use or just leave them out. There might be other problems as well once fixing that.

I would make sure to run through the different profiles (like the release profile) locally to test everything out to make sure it still works with JDK 8 and JDK 11. With moving to JDK 11 and also updating a bunch of maven plugins there could be other issues not easily seen as the default build may not have those features enabled (like building javadocs)
@cshannon I did some fixes already about javadoc. Let me check what's the issue.
By the way, I tested with `-Papache-release` but I didn't launch it recently. I'm doing a new pass now.
@cshannon javadoc seems to pass fine on my machine with `-Papache-release`. I'm doing new tests with `deploy` profile.
@cshannon do you have a failure on Javadoc ? `mvn javadoc:jar` works fine for me, just the warning about URL (same with `-Pdeploy`). So it looks ok for me ;)
My issue seems to be solved with a javadoc plugin update to 3.0.1, I will push another commit.
@cshannon thanks for the update, it seems to be "environment related" as I don't have issue. I let you push the commit with javadoc plugin 3.0.1 update. Thanks again !
Thanks ! I'm testing it ;)

@jbonofre - yeah not sure what's up, could be maven version or who knows. I found this which seemed to be my issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MJAVADOC-427 which was solved by updating to 3.0.1 as it said.
@jbonofre - something else that is wrong is that it looks like activemq-camel is now pulling in a bunch of spring classes into the jar file.
@cshannon hmmm, let me double check, it should be imported (not private). I'm checking. Thanks.
@cshannon ok I found the issue: it's the `Export-Package` which is global. I'm fixing.

@jbonofre - Found one more issue, the implementation details are missing out of the jar manifest files now. Looking at activemq-client jar the manifest no longer has things like:

`Implementation-Title: Apache ActiveMQ`
`Implementation-Version: 5.17.0-SNAPSHOT`

These details are important as there is an API to query them in the ActiveMQConnectionMetaData class.
@cshannon ok, I'm checking that as well.

The full test suite makes for a long run-fix-run cycle.  I'm thinking might be best to merge and clean these up as follow-on tasks. Thoughts?

Hello @maxfortun, thanks for the PR. Will review. Do you happen to have a JIRA to reference for this? 

If not, it is quick to open one at [Apache JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira) -- select 'ActiveMQ' as the project and 'Web Console' as the component. Release notes are generated from the JIRAs, so features and fixes like this can be communicated to users.

Thanks!

Thank you, just created the issue:

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMQ-8274

@cshannon please ignore my last comment, misreading the artifacts MANIFEST.
I pushed the fix on `activemq-camel`. I'm doing final smoke tests on my machine, but I think the PR is ready to be squashed and merged.

The main issue I see here is what you pointed out...while this prevents the error it would result in not filtering between brokers and may cause unintended behavior which isn't great either and the only real way to fix it is to make the predicate be included by OpenWire (maybe another version or what you already tried)

For the topic scenario (and using conduit subscriptions) it would work fine as selectors are not used anyways as it is pub/sub and messages are just broadcast so when the messages hit the different brokers they can be filtered there.

When using a queue with multiple consumers I would think this would lead to stuck messages. For example a scenario might be if you had 3 brokers (A, B, C) and you create consumers on A and B with different predicates but those predicates are now filtered out when creating demand with advisories. That means if a message is published to broker C that could would match the predicate on consumer on A but not B it may still be forwarded to B and now stuck.

I'm not really sure how much it matters as I doubt many people are doing this as this issue would have been brought up more often. This fix would probably be ok as long as we update the documentation on the network of brokers page and add something that specifically points out that if that field is set a network of brokers ignores it.
@jbonofre - I'm running through some tests on this now to double check everything and will report back shortly.
@cshannon cool, thanks !
@jbonofre - This looks good to me, I don't see any more issues with it
@cshannon awesome ! Thanks ! I will merge it then.
@jbonofre thanks for this one!
Just added a quick fix on `activemq-osgi` in order to work fine with any Karaf version.
For the record, you can rebase and squash, and then force push to have a single commit instead of two.
Will do.  Was looking into Jetty 10 and Jettty 11 for a hot minute-- but we'd need a JDK v11 min required
It's too early to upgrade to jetty 10 or jetty 11 as it will break the third party (Karaf), and also API change. I would target this once Pax Web/Karaf will support it.
@jbonofre and @mattrpav - I think this will do the trick. I did some testing and the StompNIOSSLTest is still fixed with this modified fix. It's pretty straight forward as you can see.

@mattrpav - agreed, there are still thread safety issues to address but narrowing this lock to secureRead() at least fixes the deadlock problem while fixing the StompNIOSSLTest issue still so it's still better than it was. It makes sense to take a look in future Jiras to improve things.

I will go ahead and merge this.
I think we should consider a v5.15.16 b/c of this. Thoughts?
Is there any particular reason someone using 5.15.15 can't upgrade to 5.16.3?
Nothing other than feels weird to me to leave a deadlock bug in an otherwise fairly stable release series.

Fair enough, nothing really against doing a release other than we said 5.15.15 was the last one. You have to draw a line somewhere but I would be ok with 5.15.16 with a limited scope (ie just fixing this issue or something) if we wanted to do that just because deadlocks are a major issue. I don't want to pull a bunch of other stuff into 5.15.16 if we did it as it's really time to get people to start upgrading.
I didn't have time yesterday to do the review, but you have my +1 ;) Thanks !

@jbonofre - thanks, @mattrpav took a look obviously so I went ahead and merged it. There's still work to be done as seen in the new Jiras opened but this fix should at least prevent the deadlock issue.
@cshannon no problem ! You did well ! I'm rebasing/fixing log4j2 update.

Is this causing the amqp test failure on java.util.UUID not serializable?

[PR-665 failing](https://ci-builds.apache.org/blue/organizations/jenkins/ActiveMQ%2FActiveMQ/detail/PR-665/2/pipeline/)
I don't think so...that test passes locally for me on the branch.
@mattrpav no, it's not related. I have a fix for flaky AMQP test due to unserialize.
@domson-tech Thanks for the PR. Can you please share kind of abstract about this K-LRU cache on the client side ? What's the purpose/abstract, how to configure it, ... ? Thanks !
@jbonofre any feedback before I merge?
@mattrpav I would like to fully test the resulting assembly first. Give me couple of days. Thanks.
As discussed on the mailing list, I did it already and I was about to create the PR.
By the way, I'm using Geronimo spec to be aligned with camel and OSGi.

@jbonofre this change is purely packaging skeleton. I know you mentioned working on full JMS 2.0 support along w/ big things like replicated-kahadb. I thought I'd pitch in to help get the ball rolling on the low-hanging fruit. There is no real code change here, so I think this PR good to merge and should slide in with your real JMS 2.0 impl work. I also broke up the 2.0 Impl work into sub-tasks here-- https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMQ-7309. This should help parallelize the effort amongst contributors.

Reviewing other projects and frameworks, I agree the geronimo vs jakarta is the real question here and I think it makes more sense to go to the Jakarta jar now as it is more target state than using geronimo.

If we go geronimo users will have this to look forward to:
gerinomo 1.1 -> geronimo 2.0 -> jakarta 2.0 -> jakarta 3.0

Alternatively, if we go jakarta now, users have this:
gerinomo 1.1 -> jakarta 2.0 -> jakarta 3.0

CXF has transitioned many spec jars to jakarta, and I suspect Camel will do the same as well. I think the alignment makes more sense for CXF and Camel to consume the dep ActiveMQ (being as ActiveMQ is the JMS provider as those ride on top of ActiveMQ), or they simply provide the <exclude/>. Either way, the JEE transition is going to force framework devs and users into being savvy with Maven <exclude/> and I do not think there is any way around that.

I'd be interested in hearing others' perspective as well.

>Either way, the JEE transition is going to force framework devs and users into being savvy with Maven and I do not think there is any way around that.
> 
> I'd be interested in hearing others' perspective as well.

@mattrpav for a usability perspective, whatever approach we take, I think just being helpful on the website is sufficient -> have a page that clearly states what is supported for JMS, what isn't, what would be the required/removed dependencies for maven, gradle and some concise examples

@jbonofre @rmannibucau I've updated this round of the PR to include geronimo-jms for the karaf artifacts. While there is no bigger Karaf fan than me, I think using jakarta as the baseline makes more sense. 

_Please here me out on these points below and if you still think we should go geronimo all the way, I'll make the change._

Most users are going to see activemq through the lens of activemq-client and its dependencies:

```
   activemq-client
      + jakarta.jms-api-2.0.3
```

vs

```
   activemq-client
      + geronimo-jms_2.0_spec-1.0-alpha-2.jar
```

Shortly, we'll have:

```
  activemq-client-jms3
      + jakarta.jms-api-3.0.0.jar
```

1. The geronimo part doesn't appear to be a stable release
2. What even is geronimo? How does this fit in with Jakarta? What is a 'spec'?
3. Shortly, we'll want to add a client for Jakarta 3 support. The dependency is going to flip on users again.
4. There is no geronimo-jms for Jakarta 3
5. Optionally, I'm happy to package up jakarta jms api jars as bundles for Karaf (which we may need to do anyway for JMS 3)

Thank you for hearing me out
Up vote for jakarta.jms-api-2.0.3
